AMENDMENTS TO THE SOUTH CAROLINA
APPELLATE COURT   RULES
1.       Rule 224(j), SCACR, is amended to read:

  (j)     Authority of an Individual Judge or Justice.  Except   where these rules require the concurrence of two or more members of an appellate   court, an individual judge or justice may grant or deny any motion or petition   on behalf of the court.  Any review of an order issued by an individual judge or   justice shall be by petition for rehearing.

2.       Rule 226(c) – (f), SCACR, is amended to read:

  (c)     Time for Petitioning and Filing Fee.  A decision of the Court   of Appeals is not final for the purpose of review by the Supreme Court until the   petition for rehearing or reinstatement has been acted on by the Court of   Appeals.  A petition for writ of certiorari shall be served on opposing counsel   and filed with proof of service with the Clerk of the Court of Appeals and the   Clerk of the Supreme Court within thirty (30) days after the petition for   rehearing or reinstatement is finally decided by the Court of Appeals.  An   original and six (6) copies of the petition shall be filed with the Supreme   Court.  The copies filed with the Supreme Court shall be accompanied by the   filing fee set by order of the Supreme Court.[1]  No filing fee shall be required in criminal   cases or petitions filed by the State of South Carolina or its agencies or   departments.  
	 
  (d)     Content of Petition.  The petition for writ of certiorari   shall contain the following:
  
    (1)     Certification by counsel for petitioner that a petition for   rehearing or reinstatement was made and finally ruled on by the Court of   Appeals.
    (2)     The questions presented for review, expressed in the terms and   circumstances of the case but without unnecessary detail.  Only those questions   raised in the Court of Appeals and in the petition for rehearing shall be   included in the petition for writ of certiorari as a question presented to the   Supreme Court.  A question presented will be deemed to include every subsidiary   question fairly comprised therein.
    (3)     A concise statement of the case, containing the facts material   to the consideration of the questions presented.
    (4)     A direct and concise argument in support of the petition.  The   argument on each question shall include citation of authority and specific   reference to pertinent portions of the Record on Appeal.  Failure of a   petitioner to present with accuracy, brevity, and clarity the information and   arguments that are essential to a ready and adequate understanding of the points   requiring consideration will be a sufficient reason for denying the petition.    The total length of a petition shall not exceed twenty-five (25)   pages.
  
  (e)     Appendix.  At the same time the petition is filed, the   petitioner shall also file two (2) copies of the Appendix with the Clerk of the   Supreme Court.  The Appendix shall include the following:
  
    (1)     A copy of the Record on Appeal and brief(s), or in   post-conviction relief matters, a copy of the Appendix, petition for writ of   certiorari, return, reply and any briefs filed under Rule 227 SCACR.
    (2)     If the matter was dismissed by the Court of Appeals for   procedural or other reasons, the Appendix shall include any documents relevant   to the dismissal including any motion to dismiss and any return or reply that   may have been filed.
    (3)     A copy of the decision of the Court of Appeals on which   certiorari is sought.
    (4)     A copy of the petition for rehearing or reinstatement filed in   the Court of Appeals and the Court’s ruling on that petition.
  
  If the Appendix contains any of the documents specified in (2) above, a copy   of the Appendix must be served on the opposing counsel and proof of service of   the Appendix must be filed when the petition for writ of certiorari is   filed.
  (f)     Return to Petition.  Within thirty (30) days after service of   the petition, respondent shall serve a copy of his return on opposing counsel,   and shall file with the Clerk of the Supreme Court one original and six (6)   copies of his return and proof of service showing that the return has been   served.  The return shall include an argument on each question and may include a   counter-statement of the case and of the questions presented for review.  The   total length of a return shall not exceed twenty-five (25) pages.  If review is   being sought regarding a post-conviction relief case, the respondent need not   file a return unless requested by the Supreme Court.  
	 

3.       The phrase “three (3) copies” is replaced with the phrase “a copy”   everywhere it appears in Rules 210(a), 211(a), 226(i), and 227(j), SCACR.

title: State v. Evins
description: Appellant Fredrick Antonio Evins was convicted of murder, first degree criminal sexual conduct (CSC), and grand larceny.  He was sentenced to death for the murder, thirty years imprisonment for CSC, and five years for grand larceny.  This appeal consolidates his direct appeal with the mandatory review provisions of S.C. text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				The State, 
				Respondent, 
				v.
				Fredrick Antonio Evins, 
				Appellant.
			
		
	


Appeal from Spartanburg County
Â Edward W. Miller, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26329
Heard March 8, 2007 - Filed May 14, 2007Â Â Â  
AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				Deputy Chief Attorney for Capital Appeals Robert M. Dudek, and Appellate Defender Aileen P. Clare, both of Columbia, for Appellant.
				Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, Assistant Attorney General Derrick K. McFarland, all of Columbia, and Solicitor Harold W. Gowdy, III, of Spartanburg, for Respondent.
			
		
	


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  Appellant Fredrick Antonio Evins (â€œEvinsâ€) was convicted of murder, first degree criminal sexual conduct (CSC), and grand larceny.Â  He was sentenced to death for the murder, thirty years imprisonment for CSC, and five years for grand larceny.Â  This appeal consolidates his direct appeal with the mandatory review provisions of S.C. Code Ann. Â§16-3-25 (1985).Â  We affirm the convictions and sentences.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
The victim in this case, Rhonda Ward (â€œWardâ€™), was the manager of a convenience store in Spartanburg.Â  One early morning in February 2003, Evins approached Ward in the parking lot of the store on her way into work.Â  Ward spoke to Evins briefly before he lead her back to her car where she got in the driverâ€™s side and he got into the passenger side.Â  Â Surveillance cameras at the store captured the exchange between Ward and Evins. Â Two days later, Wardâ€™s naked body was found face down in an apple orchard.Â  She had been sexually assaulted and stabbed twelve times. Â 
After police discovered Evins had been driving Wardâ€™s car on the day of the murder, he was arrested and subsequently confessed to Wardâ€™s murder.Â  Initially, Evins denied having had sex with Ward; instead, he claimed another man was with him in the woods and insisted that Evins kill Ward.Â  However, upon being taken to the hospital for DNA testing, Evins admitted he had had sex with Ward on the day of her death.Â  At trial, Evins claimed he and Ward had been engaged in a long-term, consensual sexual relationship.Â  He testified that on the day of her death, he and Ward were engaged in sexual intercourse outside in an apple field, when Ward became angry with him for refusing to leave his girlfriend.Â  According to Evins, Ward wielded a knife, and wound up getting stabbed.Â 
 
The jury convicted Evins of murder, kidnapping, first degree CSC, and grand larceny.Â  After a separate sentencing phase, Evins was sentenced to death for murder, thirty years for CSC and five years for grand larceny.Â  Evins raises the following issues for this Courtâ€™s review:[1]

	I. Did the trial court err in denying Evinsâ€™ motion for a change of venue based on pre-trial publicity?
	II. Did the trial court err in ruling the stateâ€™s exercise of peremptory challenges did not violate 
	Batson v. Kentucky?Â  
	III. Did the trial court err in excusing three African-American potential jurors for cause?Â  
	
	IV. Did the trial court err in admitting certain photographs of the victimâ€™s body at sentencing?

LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Pre-trial Publicity- Change of Venue
In September 2002, approximately five months prior to the murder in this case, the body of a woman named Demaris Huff was found near a creek beside a walking trail near a park in Spartanburg.Â  She had been strangled and was nude except for a pair of socks.Â  DNA testing revealed that semen found on Huff matched that of Evins.Â  The case remained unsolved until Evinsâ€™ subsequent arrest for the February 2003 murder of Ward.Â  At that time, after DNA testing, authorities also charged Evins with Huffâ€™s murder. Â The Huff murder charges were pending at the time of Evinsâ€™ trial for the murder of Ward.Â 
 
Evins moved for a change of venue based upon extensive pre-trial publicity, much of which linked Evins to both murders.Â  The trial court ruled in a pre-trial hearing that it would allow Evins latitude in the voir dire of potential jurors to determine if they had any prior knowledge of Evins and/or the Huff murder.Â  At the conclusion of voir dire, the defense renewed its motion for a change of venue, indicating that a total of thirty-nine people out of the jury pool of sixty-eight had heard something about the case.Â  By defense counselâ€™s count, seven of the twelve jurors seated had some knowledge of the case.Â  The trial court declined to change venue, concluding that all of the jurors who had any prior knowledge of the case had indicated they could set aside any information and would not consider it.Â  The court also noted the defense had used only nine of its ten peremptory challenges to remove potential jurors.Â  Evins now contends the denial of his motion to change venue constituted an abuse of discretion.Â  We disagree.Â Â Â  Â  

A motion to change venue is addressed to the sound discretion of the trial judge and will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion.Â  Sheppard v. State, 357 S.C. 646, 594 S.E.2d 462 (2004); State v. Manning, 329 S.C. 1, 495 S.E.2d 191 (1997) (finding trial court abused discretion by granting the Stateâ€™s motion to change venue based on pretrial publicity because no evidentiary facts supported finding of actual juror prejudice towards the State). When a trial judge bases the denial of a motion for a change of venue because of pretrial publicity upon an adequate voir dire examination of the jurors, his decision will not be disturbed absent extraordinary circumstances. State v. Caldwell, 300 S.C. 494, 388 S.E.2d 816 (1990).Â  When jurors have been exposed to pretrial publicity, a denial of a change of venue is not error where the jurors are found to have the ability to set aside any impressions or opinions and render a verdict based on the evidence presented at trial.Â  State v. Tucker, 334 S.C. 1, 512 S.E.2d 99 (1999); Manning, 329 S.C. at 1, 495 S.E.2d at 191. Â Â Therefore, mere exposure to pretrial publicity does not automatically disqualify a prospective juror.Â  Id.Â  The relevant question is not whether the community remembered the case, but whether the jurors had such fixed opinions that they could not judge impartially the guilt of the defendant.Â  Id.Â  It is the defendantâ€™s burden to demonstrate actual juror prejudice as a result of such publicity.Â  Caldwell, 300 S.C. at 494, 388 S.E.2d at 816.
In Rideau v. Louisiana, 373 U.S. 723 (1963), the United States Supreme Court found reversible error in a trial courtâ€™s refusal to grant a motion for a change of venue due to the effect of pretrial publicity.Â  There, the Court found that the people of Calcasieu Parish in Lake Charles, Louisiana, were â€œexposed repeatedly and in depth to the spectacle of Rideau personally confessing in detail to the crimes with which he was later to be charged.â€Â  Id.Â  The Court noted that three members of the jury which convicted Rideau had seen and heard Rideauâ€™s televised â€œinterviewâ€ in which he confessed to the sheriff, and that two members of the jury were deputy sheriffs of Calcasieu Parish.Â  Id.Â  The Court found Rideauâ€™s due process rights had been compromised by such a procedure.Â  Â Id. The present case is clearly inapposite.
We find Evins has demonstrated no prejudice from the denial of his motion.Â  Both the trial court and defense counsel conducted a thorough voir dire of the jury pool.Â  Additionally, all members of the jury who had any knowledge of Evins or the Huff murder due to pre-trial publicity indicated they could put that knowledge aside.Â  Further, the defense used only nine of its peremptory challenges.Â  Evins contends, however, that one juror had read about both crimes and connected them mentally such that â€œshe could not be expected to disregard the image created by the articles.â€Â  Evinsâ€™ depiction of the jurorâ€™s response is overstated.Â  Â Â The juror testified on voir dire that the only thing she had heard was that the crime had taken place; she specifically testified that she knew no details, did not know the location, she had formed no opinion, could put aside what she had heard, and could be fair and impartial.Â  This is simply not akin to the situation in Rideau.Â  
 
We find this case more akin to Sheppard, 357 S.C. at 646, 594 S.E.2d at 462, in which the defendant claimed he was entitled to a change of venue due to extensive pretrial publicity where, out of eighty-seven potential jurors, all but five had been exposed to pretrial publicity.Â  Noting our holdings in Manning and Caldwell, we found the defendant had not met his burden of demonstrating actual juror prejudice as a result of the publicity.Â  Sheppard, 357 S.C. at 655, 597 S.E.2d at 468. We held, â€œ[m]ere exposure to pretrial publicity does not automatically disqualify a prospective juror. Instead, the relevant question is not whether the community remembered the case, but whether the jurors had such fixed opinions that they could not judge impartially the guilt of the defendant.â€Â  Id.Â  
 
Moreover, Evins concedes that evidence of the Huff murder was properly admitted at the sentencing phase of trial. Â Accordingly, Evinsâ€™ complaint regarding pretrial publicity is necessarily limited to the guilt phase of his trial.Â  Given the overwhelming evidence presented during that phase of trial, and the fact that Evins actually admitted to stabbing Ward, we find Evins has suffered no prejudice.Â  Accordingly, the trial courtâ€™s denial of the motion to change venue is affirmed.
 
II. Batson Motion
Evins next asserts the trial court erred in denying his Batson[2] motion and ruling that two of the Stateâ€™s peremptory challenges were not racially motivated.Â  We disagree.Â  We find the solicitorâ€™s stated reasons for striking the jurors were race-neutral.Â  
 
There were a total of twelve African-American venire members out of the pool of sixty-three potential jurors.Â  During jury selection, the state exercised a total of seven peremptory challenges, striking three African American and four white potential jurors.Â  The jury was ultimately comprised of eleven white jurors, one black juror, and one each white and black alternate.Â  Evins complains that two of the African-Americans were struck in violation of Batson.[3] Â We disagree.Â   
In response to Evinsâ€™ Batson motion, the solicitor explained that he struck Juror #78 because she had recently lost two sons in a felony DUI, for which the perpetrator had received only a six-year sentence.Â  The solicitor was concerned that the juror would weigh the sentence given to the defendant of a felony DUI in which her sons were killed with the potential death sentence she would be considering in Evinsâ€™ case.Â  Additionally, he addressed the fact that the solicitorâ€™s office prosecuted the case and the public defenderâ€™s office defended the defendant.Â  The trial court ruled the solicitorâ€™s explanation satisfied the test required in Batson.Â  
 
As to the other juror, Juror #399, the solicitor argued that the juror was â€œbeyond vacillation on the death penalty.Â  He is clearly life prone.Â  And thatâ€™s why we struck him.â€Â  The trial court ruled the solicitorâ€™s reason was race-neutral, specifically stating, â€œI do agree with his assessment that [the juror] did appear to have - was one of the jurors with the largest problems with finding - would have one of the hardest times finding death.Â  So I do agree with that.â€Â 
 
Evins asserts the solicitorâ€™s stated reasons were mere pretext.Â  We disagree.Â 
 
The Equal Protection Clause of the Fourteenth Amendment to the Constitution prohibits the striking of a venire person on the basis of race or gender.Â  State v. Rayfield, 369 S.C. 106, 631 S.E.2d 244 (2006); State v. Shuler, 344 S.C. 604, 545 S.E.2d 805 (2001).Â  The proper procedure for a Batson hearing is set forth in State v. Adams, 322 S.C. 114, 470 S.E.2d 366 (1996) (citing Purkett v. Elem, 514 U.S. 765 (1995)). Â After a party objects to a jury strike, the proponent of the strike must offer a facially race-neutral explanation.Â  Once the proponent states a reason that is race-neutral, the burden is on the party challenging the strike to show the explanation is mere pretext, either by showing similarly situated members of another race were seated on the jury or that the reason given for the strike is so fundamentally implausible as to constitute mere pretext despite a lack of disparate treatment.Â  Adams, 322 S.C. at 123-24, 470 S.E.2d at 371-72.Â  The burden of persuading the court that a Batson violation has occurred remains at all times on the opponent of the strike.Â  State v. Haigler, 334 S.C. 623, 515 S.E.2d 88 (1999). 
 
â€œTypically, the decisive question becomes whether counselâ€™s race-neutral explanation for a peremptory challenge should be believed. . . . [T]here is seldom much evidence in the record bearing on that issue, and the trial courtâ€™s findings regarding purposeful discrimination necessarily will rest largely on the evaluation of demeanor and credibility of counsel. Therefore, those findings are given great deference and will not be set aside unless clearly erroneous.â€Â  State v. Cochran, 369 S.C. 308, 631 S.E.2d 294 (Ct. App. 2006) citing State v. Guess, 318 S.C. 269, 457 S.E.2d 6 (Ct.App. 1995).
As this Court held in Payton v. Kearse, 329 S.C. 51, 495 S.E.2d 205 (1998), the right to serve on a jury and not to be discriminated against because of race or gender belongs to the potential juror, not a litigant.Â  This is so because a defendant has no right to trial by a particular jury.Â  Adams, 322 S.C. at 126, 470 S.E.2d at 373.
We find the record supports the trial courtâ€™s finding that the stateâ€™s explanation for its peremptory challenges of these two jurors were race-neutral.Â  The fact that Juror #78 had had two sons killed in a felony DUI, and the perpetrator had received only six years imprisonment was sufficient reason for the solicitor to believe that this juror might be reluctant to impose a death sentence.Â  Moreover, when initially questioned by the trial court as to whether she could be a fair and impartial juror, she responded, â€œwell, your Honor, I done been through this before, so it would be kind of hard for me to, you know. . .â€ Â When questioned further as to whether she could find a defendant either guilty or not guilty depending on what she heard, she went on to state, â€œWell, to be truthful, I donâ€™t know. . . .Your Honor, I still - I canâ€™t make up my mind.Â  I donâ€™t know what happened to my two sons, and I havenâ€™t got over it yet.â€Â  Although she ultimately testified that she would honor her oath if selected to be a fair and impartial juror, she nonetheless maintained when asked if she knew any reason why she could not serve on this jury that serving would be difficult for her.Â  In sum, although her answers varied somewhat, we simply cannot say the solicitorâ€™s proffered reason for striking Juror #78 was not race-neutral or that the solicitorâ€™s stated reasons were pretext.
As for Juror #399, the solicitorâ€™s stated reason for striking him was that he was likely the most pro-life person in the jury venire.Â  When asked whether he could serve as a fair and impartial juror, he responded, â€œPossibly, I could, but I donâ€™t know.â€Â  When questioned about whether he could sentence someone to death, he repeatedly stated, â€œThatâ€™s a tough one. . . .Â  Well, like I said, I never really thought about it, but that would still be just like killing somebody.Â  I mean, thatâ€™s basically, the same thing to me. . . . Thatâ€™s just what I - thatâ€™s just he way I feel right now, you know.Â  Like I say, I never really thought about it. . . .Â  So, I mean, death is death.. . . â€ Â When the trial court asked, â€œSo, are - you donâ€™t - what youâ€™re telling me is that you donâ€™t believe in killing; is that right?,â€ the juror responded, â€œWell, I like life better than death.Â  Thatâ€™s a tough one, Iâ€™m going to tell you.â€Â  When told by the trial court that they need to know where he stood, the juror concluded, â€œI probably could.Â  But then again, I hear this little voice saying, you know, itâ€™s not right, but I probably could.â€Â 
 
Vacillating responses to voir dire questions regarding the death penalty will support the use of a peremptory strike against a Batson challenge. Â State v. Bell, 305 S.C. 11, 406 S.E.2d 165 (1991); State v. Green, 301 S.C. 347, 392 S.E.2d 157 (1990); State v. Elmore, 300 S.C. 130, 386 S.E.2d 769 (1989).Â  Where the Solicitor perceives a person will have difficulty imposing the death penalty, he may exercise a peremptory challenge against that juror upon this ground as a racially neutral reason.Â  Bell. 305 S.C. at 15, 406 S.E.2d at 168. Â Â 
Here, the jurorâ€™s vacillation and reluctance to impose a death sentence is quite evident.Â  Further, although Evins now points to several white jurors who were seated on the jury who also vacillated in their responses regarding a sentence of death, Evins did not raise this point at the time of his Batson challenge during the trial and therefore failed to meet his burden of demonstrating pretext to the trial court.Â  In any event, the four white jurors cited by Evins on appeal simply did not vacillate in their responses to the same degree as Juror #399.Â  None of these jurors were nearly as equivocal in their responses concerning the death penalty.Â  Accordingly, the trial court properly ruled the solicitorâ€™s stated reason for striking him was race-neutral, and Evinsâ€™ Batson motion was properly denied.
III. Juror Disqualification
Evins next contends the trial court erred in disqualifying three African American venire members from serving on the jury.Â  Juror #258 was disqualified because of her reluctance to impose a sentence of death; Juror #182 was disqualified due to her predisposition to impose a sentence of death; and Juror #134 was disqualified due to both his reluctance to impose a death sentence and the fact that he had charges pending against him for which he was being prosecuted by the solicitor, and represented by the Public Defenderâ€™s office (which also represented Evins).Â  Evins asserts these jurors were improperly disqualified.Â  We disagree.
A prospective juror may be excluded for cause when his or her views on capital punishment would prevent or substantially impair the performance of his duties as a juror in accordance with his instructions and his oath.Â  S.C.Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-20(E) (2003) (juror may not be excused in a death penalty case unless his beliefs or attitudes against capital punishment would render him unable to return a verdict according to law); State v. Lindsey, Op. No. 26268, (S.C. Sup. Ct. filed Feb. 20, 2007) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 6 at 68); State v. Sapp, 366 S.C. 283, 621 S.E.2d 883 (2005) (citing Wainwright v. Witt, 469 U.S. 412 (1985)). When reviewing the trial courtâ€™s qualification or disqualification of prospective jurors, the responses of the challenged juror must be examined in light of the entire voir dire.Â  Id.Â  The determination whether a juror is qualified to serve in a capital case is within the sole discretion of the trial judge and is not reversible on appeal unless wholly unsupported by the evidence.Â  Id.Â  A jurorâ€™s disqualification will not be disturbed on appeal if there is a reasonable basis from which the trial court could have concluded that the juror would not have been able to faithfully discharge his responsibilities as a juror under the law. Â State v. Green, 301 S.C. 347, 392 S.E.2d 157 (1990).Â  Deference must be paid to the trial court who sees and hears the juror.Â  Id.Â  There will be situations where a trial court is left with definite impression that prospective juror would be unable to faithfully and impartially apply the law and this is why deference must be paid to a trial court who sees and hears the juror.Â  Wainwright v. Witt, 469 U.S. 412 (1985).Â  
 
As discussed below, we find the trial court properly disqualified these jurors under Wainwright.
A.Â  Juror # 258
Juror #258 originally testified that she could not give the death penalty because she did not feel that it was her right to give a man death.Â  Juror #258 then indicated she could impose a sentence of death under certain circumstances.Â  When asked thereafter if she could sign her name to a verdict form imposing a sentence of death, Juror #258 replied, â€œ No.â€Â  She explained the reason for this as being that given her job in the public, she could be a target for anybody, so she wouldnâ€™t want to sign her name.Â  When the trial court indicated her name would be protected, she indicated she could sign a verdict form for death.Â  When questioned by the solicitor, Juror #258 vacillated between being opposed to the death penalty, and appearing to believe it would be appropriate for most murders.Â  Ultimately, however, when asked by the solicitor if she had a choice between life in prison or death, the juror answered that she would always pick life in prison.Â 
 
Given the variations in Juror #258â€™s responses and statement that she would always pick life in prison over death, the trial court did not abuse its discretion in disqualifying her because it appears she could not have discharged her duties in accordance with the law.Â  Â Id.Â  
 
B.Â  Juror #182
During voir dire, Juror #182 stated she was a Type 3 juror who would hear all the evidence before deciding upon an appropriate sentence.Â  On examination by the solicitor, however, Juror #182 strongly indicated that she would always give the death penalty to anyone who intentionally kills another.Â  Upon further examination, Juror #182 explained that she would give life only to someone who unintentionally kills another, like self-defense.Â  Juror #182 ultimately concluded that â€œif you intentionally kill somebody, you know what you were doing, death penalty, but self-defense, life sentence.â€Â  
 
Again, it is clear this juror was predisposed to recommend a sentence of death in the case of an intentional killing such that there is a reasonable basis from which the trial court could have concluded she would not have been able to faithfully discharge her responsibilities as a juror under the law.Â  We find she was properly disqualified under Wainwright.Â  See also State v. Sapp, 366 S.C. at 283, 621 S.E.2d at 883. 
 
C.Â  Juror # 134
When asked whether, after considering all of the aggravating and mitigating circumstances, he could return a sentence of death, Juror #134 testified that he was not in favor of the death penalty and that he â€œreally would have to be persuadedâ€ to give the death penalty.Â  Thereafter, when asked if he could sign his name to a death verdict, Juror #134 responded that, depending on the facts, he could sign a death verdict form.Â  However, he subsequently described himself as a Number 2 juror - a juror who would not give the death penalty.Â  Upon further inquiry by the solicitor regarding the death penalty, Juror #134 responded:Â  â€œIâ€™ve just always been the type that when I see it on TV or something about the death penalty, Iâ€™m always against it.Â  There hasnâ€™t been one case yet where I said he deserves it.â€
We find the record supports the trial courtâ€™s disqualification of Juror #134.[4]Â  Wainwright, 469 U.S. at 412 (holding that where trial court is left with definite impression that prospective juror would be unable to faithfully and impartially apply the law, it is within his discretion to disqualify a potential juror); see also State v. Council, 335 S.C. 1, 515 S.E.2d 508 (1999) (ultimate consideration of the judge concerning juror qualification is that the juror be unbiased, impartial and able to carry out the law as explained to him).
IV. Sentencing Phase Photographs 

Lastly, Evins asserts the trial court committed error at sentencing in admitting seven photographs of the victim, contending they served no legitimate purpose and served only to inflame the jury.Â Â  In particular, Evins contests the admission of Exhibit numbers 70 and 71, which reveal that the victim had defecated on herself.Â  We find the photographs were properly admitted.
The relevance, materiality and admissibility of photographs are matters within the sound discretion of the trial court, and the trial courtâ€™s ruling on such issues will be disturbed only upon a showing of an abuse of discretion.Â  State v. Tucker, 324 S.C. 155, 478 S.E.2d 260 (1996), cert. denied, 520 U.S. 1200 (1997).Â  The purpose of the sentencing phase in a capital trial is to â€œdirect the juryâ€™s attention to the specific circumstances of the crime and the characteristics of the offender.â€Â  State v. Matthews, 296 S.C. 379, 373 S.E.2d 587 (1988), cert. denied, 489 U.S. 1091 (1989).Â  Photographs may be offered as evidence in extenuation, mitigation, or aggravation. Â State v. Haselden, 353 S.C. 190, 577 S.E.2d 445 (2003).Â  In the sentencing phase, the scope of the probative value of such photos is much broader than at the guilt or innocence phase.Â  Id.Â  See also State v. WeikÂ¸ 356 S.C. 76, 587 S.E.2d 683 (2002); State v. Franklin, 318 S.C. 47, 456 S.E.2d 357 (1995).Â Â  In determining whether to recommend a sentence of death, the jury may be permitted to see photographs which depict the bodies of the murder victims in substantially the same condition in which the defendant left them.Â  State v. Kornahrens, 290 S.C. 281, 350 S.E.2d 180 (1986).Â Â  There is no abuse of discretion if the offered photograph serves to corroborate testimony.Â  State v. Johnson, 338 S.C. 114, 525 S.E.2d 519 (2000).
Exhibit 70 is a 4â€ x 6â€ photograph of the victimâ€™s body, taken from a distance of several feet away.Â Â  It reveals the victim lying in a grassy field, naked and face down, with her right arm stretched up over her head, and her left arm bent and stretched out to the left.Â  Upon close inspection, a small amount of feces is visible.Â  Exhibit 71 is a photograph of victimâ€™s body taken from a further distance away, and was taken from an angle above the victimâ€™s head.Â  The feces is not clearly visible in Exhibit 71.Â  We find the photographs were properly admitted to show the victim in substantially the same condition as Evins left her, and to corroborate the testimony that the victim had defecated on herself.Â  The photographs are not unnecessarily gruesome or disturbing.Â  Accordingly, the trial court did not abuse its discretion in admitting the photographs.
 
PROPORTIONALITY REVIEW
We have conducted the proportionality review as required by S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-25(C), and we find the sentence in this case was not the result of passion, prejudice, or any other arbitrary factor. Furthermore, a review of similar cases illustrates that imposing the death sentence in this case would be neither excessive nor disproportionate in light of the crime and the defendant.Â  State v. Downs, 361 S.C. 141, 604 S.E.2d 377 (2004) (death sentence warranted where defendant was convicted of murder, kidnapping, and first-degree criminal sexual conduct with a minor); State v. Stokes, 345 S.C. 368, 548 S.E.2d 202 (2001); State v. Council, 335 S.C. 1, 515 S.E.2d 508 (1999) cert. denied 528 U.S. 1050 (1999); State v. Tucker, 319 S.C. 425, 462 S.E.2d 263 (1995) cert. denied 516 U.S. 1080 (1996).Â  
 
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, we affirm Evinsâ€™ convictions and sentences.
AFFIRMED.
MOORE, BURNETT, PLEICONES, JJ., and Acting Justice Edward B. Cottingham, concur.

[1]Â We have re-framed the seven issues raised by Evins.
[2]Â Batson v. Kentucky, 476 U.S. 79 (1986).
[3]Â Evins does not contest the strike of Juror # 154 on appeal.
[4] In addition to Juror #134â€™s views on the death penalty, the solicitor also explained to the court that Juror #134 had charges pending against him for which he was being prosecuted by the solicitorâ€™s office and represented by the public defenderâ€™s office.Â  The solicitor argued that the combination of the jurorâ€™s views on the death penalty and the pending charges disqualified Juror #134. Â Because we find that Juror #134 was properly disqualified on the basis of his views on the death penalty, we decline to address the issue of whether he was properly disqualified because of the pending charges.

text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Jimmy Hill, Respondent,
				v.
				Eagle Motor Lines, Employer and Alabama Truckers Association C/O Attenta, Carrier, Appellants.
			
		
	


Appeal from Marlboro County
Â Paul M. Burch, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26330
Heard November 15, 2006 - Filed May 21, 2007Â Â  

AFFIRMED IN PART; REVERSED IN PART


	
		
			
				R. Mark Davis and William Thomas Bacon, IV, both of McAngus, Goudelock & Courie, of Charleston, for Appellants.
				Steve Wukela, Jr., of Wukela Law Firm, of Florence, for Respondent.
			
		
	


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL: In this workersâ€™ compensation case, Eagle Motor Lines and Alabama Truckers Association c/o Attenta (collectively, â€œAppellantsâ€) argue that the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission did not have jurisdiction over the claim of Jimmy Hill (â€œRespondentâ€), and that Respondentâ€™s injuries are not compensable under the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act.Â  We affirm in part and reverse in part, holding that the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission had jurisdiction over Respondentâ€™s claim and that Respondent suffered compensable injuries.Â Â 
 
Factual/Procedural BackgroundÂ Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
 
Respondent, a resident of South Carolina, completed an application for employment as a truck driver with Appellant Eagle Motor Lines (â€œEmployerâ€).Â  Thereafter, Employerâ€™s recruiting manager telephoned Respondent at his home in South Carolina and requested Respondent travel to Employerâ€™s headquarters in Alabama to complete an employee screening process.Â  Respondent traveled to Alabama where he completed a drug screening test, a driving test, and other orientation procedures before being assigned a truck.Â  During the course of his employment, Respondentâ€™s driving route traversed several states along the east coast.Â  
 
In 2001, Respondent suffered a brain injury and a broken rib when his truck overturned while driving through Virginia. As a result, Respondent is disabled and unable to return to work as a truck driver.Â  Respondent claimed entitlement to medical and compensation benefits. Appellants initially paid Respondentâ€™s medical bills and disability benefits, but terminated benefits after Respondent suffered a stroke allegedly caused by a confrontation with a nurse who was handling Respondentâ€™s workersâ€™ compensation case.Â  
 
Respondent filed a Form 50 and Appellants denied Respondentâ€™s claim.Â  Following a hearing before the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission (â€œCommissionâ€), the single commissioner found the Commission had jurisdiction over Respondentâ€™s claim because: (1) Respondent was hired in South Carolina during a telephone conversation with Employerâ€™s recruiter; (2) Employer was not exempt from the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act because it had four or more employees in South Carolina; and (3) Employer subjected itself to the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act by filing for workersâ€™ compensation coverage in South Carolina.Â  The commissioner also found Respondent suffered compensable injuries and ordered Appellants to continue providing benefits to Respondent.Â 
 
On appeal, the Commissionâ€™s appellate panel affirmed the decision of the single commissioner.Â  On appeal to the circuit court, the court affirmed the appellate panel on all grounds of appeal except the issue of jurisdiction, which the court remanded to the Commission for reconsideration.
This case was certified to this Court from the court of appeals pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR.Â  Appellants raise the following issues for review:

	
		
			I. 
			Did the circuit err in failing 
			to decide whether the Commission had jurisdiction over Respondentâ€™s 
			workersâ€™ compensation claim?  
 
		
		
			II. 
			Did the circuit err in failing 
			to find that the Commission did not have jurisdiction over 
			Respondentâ€™s claim because Respondent was not hired in South 
			Carolina?
 
		
		
			III.  
			
			Did the circuit court err in 
			failing to find that the Commission did not have jurisdiction over 
			Respondentâ€™s claim because Employer did not have four or more 
			employees in South Carolina?
 
		
		
			IV. 
			Did the circuit court err in 
			affirming the Commissionâ€™s findings that Respondentâ€™s physical brain 
			injury, stroke, and psychological illness were compensable?
		
	

Standard ofÂ  Review
The Administrative Procedures Act (APA), S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-310 et. seq. (2005 & Supp. 2006), governs appellate review of a final decision from an administrative agency.Â  Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 455, 535 S.E.2d 438, 442 (2000).Â  Under the APA, this Court must determine whether the findings of fact of the Commissonâ€™s appellate panel are supported by substantial evidence in the record and whether the panelâ€™s decision is affected by an error of law.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(5) (Supp. 2006); Baxter v. Martin Bros., Inc., 368 S.C. 510, 513, 630 S.E.2d 42, 43 (2006). 
 
When the jurisdiction of the Commission is at issue, the reviewing court is not bound by the Commissionâ€™s findings of fact upon which jurisdiction is dependent.Â  Gray v. Club Group, Ltd., 339 S.C. 173, 181, 528 S.E.2d 435, 439 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  If the factual issue before the Commissionâ€™s appellate panel involved a jurisdictional question, this Courtâ€™s review is governed by the preponderance of the evidence standard.Â  Id.Â  â€œIn determining jurisdictional questions, doubts of jurisdiction will be resolved in favor of inclusion of employees within workersâ€™ compensation coverage rather than exclusion.â€Â  Wilson v. Georgetown County, 316 S.C. 92, 94, 447 S.E.2d 841, 842 (1994).
Law/Analysis
I.Â  The circuit courtâ€™s remand of the jurisdictional issue.
Appellants argue the circuit court erred in failing to rule on whether the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission had jurisdiction over Respondentâ€™s workersâ€™ compensation claim.Â  We agree.Â 
 
The circuit court has both the power and duty to review the entire record in order to find the jurisdictional facts without regard to the conclusion of the Commission on the issue of jurisdiction.Â  White v. J. T. Strahan Co., 244 S.C. 120, 125, 135 S.E.2d 720, 723 (1964).Â  Accordingly, the court must decide the jurisdictional question in accord with the preponderance of the evidence, bearing in mind that the basic purpose of the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act is to include, rather than exclude, employers and employees within its coverage.Â  Id.Â  Here, the geographical facts and circumstances of Respondentâ€™s hiring and employment were determinative of whether the Commission had jurisdiction over Respondentâ€™s claim.Â  Therefore, the circuit court had the power and duty to decide the jurisdictional issue and erred by remanding the issue to the Commission for reconsideration.Â  
 
II.Â  Jurisdiction in the state where an employee is hired
Appellants argue that the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission did not have jurisdiction over Respondentâ€™s claim because Respondent was neither hired nor employed in South Carolina.Â  We disagree.Â  
 
An employee covered by the provisions of the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act is authorized to file his claim under the laws of the state where he is hired, the state where he is injured, or the state where his employment is located.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-15-10 (1976).Â  The partiesâ€™ central dispute concerns where Respondent was hired.Â  
 
The employer-employee relationship is the jurisdictional foundation upon which workersâ€™ compensation is awarded; the existence of a contract, not the commencement of work, establishes the employer-employee relationship.Â  Oâ€™Briant v. Daniel Constr. Co., 279 S.C. 254, 256, 305 S.E.2d 241, 243 (1983).Â  Accordingly, the situs of the contract determines where an employee was hired for purposes of determining jurisdiction under Â§ 42-15-10.Â  Moore v. N. Amer. Van Lines, 310 S.C. 236, 238-39, 423 S.E.2d 116, 118 (1992).Â  The place of contracting is where the minds of the parties meet or the place where the final act occurred which made a binding contract.Â  Id.Â  Where acceptance is given over the telephone, â€œthe place of contracting is where the acceptor speaks his acceptance.â€Â  Oâ€™Briant, 279 S.C. at 256, 305 S.E.2d at 243.Â  
 
The single commissioner relied on Oâ€™Briant v. Daniel Construction Co. in finding that Respondent was hired in South Carolina.Â  In Oâ€™Briant, the employee, a construction worker, initially filled out an employment application with a construction company at its Georgia office.Â  The employee was not offered a job at the time, but the construction company later contacted him by telephone at his home in South Carolina offering him employment on a construction site in Georgia.Â  The employee accepted the job offer over the telephone.Â  279 S.C. at 255-56, 305 S.E.2d at 242.Â  The Court found that although the employee signed his application and enrollment card in the Georgia office, was hired to work at a job site in Georgia, was paid in Georgia, and received his fatal injuries in Georgia, the final act which created a binding contract occurred when the employee verbally accepted the job over the telephone in South Carolina.Â  Id. at 256, 305 S.E.3d at 243. Â Therefore, the Court held that the employee was hired in South Carolina and the Commission had jurisdiction under Â§ 42-15-10. 
 
We find the present case to be indistinguishable from Oâ€™Briant.Â  Pursuant to another employeeâ€™s recommendation,[1] Respondent called Employer at its office in Alabama and spoke with the recruiting manager about being hired as a driver.Â  The recruiting manager mailed Respondent an employment application to his home in South Carolina, which Respondent filled out and returned to Employerâ€™s office in Alabama.Â Â  Â After filling out the application and sending it in, Respondent received a telephone call from the recruiting manager a few months later informing Respondent that his application had been approved and that Employer had a position open for him.Â  The recruiting manager informed Respondent that he needed to travel to Alabama for drug screening and a road test; to attend orientation; and to receive his truck assignment.Â  Employer promised to provide, and in fact did provide, Respondentâ€™s travel and lodging expenses for this trip.Â  Â Once in Alabama, and after drug screening and a road test, the recruiting manager certified Respondent for driving and gave Respondent his first assignment and a $150 advance for road expenses.Â  Respondent left Alabama with a truck and headed towards his first delivery destination.Â  
 
Appellants argue that the purpose of the phone interview and employment application was to pre-screen potential employees before bringing them to Alabama for the last steps of the hiring process.Â  We find this argument to be unpersuasive.Â  Based on the facts, we agree with the Commission that any drug tests, road tests, and paperwork completed by Respondent in Alabama were simply incidental to the hiring of Respondent.[2]Â  Clearly a meeting of the minds had to occur before Respondent traveled to Alabama to meet Employer, and before Employer promised to finance such a trip.Â  We therefore find that Employer hired Respondent during the telephone conversation in which Employer notified Respondent that there was a job opening for him and arranged for Respondent to travel to Alabama and commence work.Â  Â Accordingly, the situs of the contract was in South Carolina and the Commission has jurisdiction over Respondentâ€™s claim.Â 
 
Respondent finds additional support for the Commissionâ€™s jurisdiction under Â§ 42-15-10 because his place of employment was in South Carolina.Â  In order to determine where a claimantâ€™s employment is located for purposes of Â§ 42-15-10, South Carolina has adopted the â€œbase of operationsâ€ rule.Â  Voss v. RAMCO, Inc., 325 S.C. 560, 482 S.E.2d 582 (Ct. App. 1997) (citing Holland v. W.C.A.B. (Pep Boys), 586 A.2d 988 (Pa. Commw. Ct. 1990)).Â  Under the base of operations rule, â€œthe workerâ€™s employment is located at the employerâ€™s place of business to which he reports, from which he receives his work assignments, and from which he starts his road trips, regardless of where the work is performed.â€Â  Holman v. Bulldog Trucking Co., 311 S.C. 341, 346, 428 S.E.2d 889, 892 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  
 
Although transient employees such as Respondent do not always fit squarely within the base of operations test, we find that based on the specific facts and circumstances of this case, Respondentâ€™s employment was located in South Carolina.Â  Respondent received his work assignment from dispatch at his South Carolina home; started his road trips from his home; used drop yards in South Carolina; kept his truck at his home on the weekends; and received his paycheck at his home in South Carolina.Â  Although Respondent was required to call the Alabama office at the end of each delivery in order to find out where to pick up his next load, he was not required to report to the Alabama office for duty or return to Alabama after completing each assignment.Â  Employer also did not require Respondent to maintain and wash the truck at the Alabama terminal.Â  Additionally, Employerâ€™s trucks were not licensed in Alabama, but Oklahoma.Â  Cf. Holman, 311 S.C. 341, 428 S.E.2d 889 (holding that an employee truck driver who lived in South Carolina was nevertheless employed in Georgia for purposes of jurisdiction under Â§ 42-15-10 because Georgia is where he reported for duty each day; picked up and returned his company truck; received work assignments; reported to dispatch; was required to call in during the course of work; maintained and washed his truck; filed trip logs; and received his paycheck).
Moreover, based on the testimony of Employerâ€™s officers, retaining drivers in states located throughout Employerâ€™s shipping areas benefited Employer in several ways.Â  Primarily, it saved Employer money by reducing the number of miles required by drivers to complete jobs and by decreasing the amount of â€œdead headâ€ time due to the driversâ€™ proximity to the pick-up locations of their cargo.Â  Officers of Employer also testified that this system served to attract potential employees who would be enticed by the idea of spending weekends at home.Â  In our opinion, and in keeping with general concepts of due process, Employer should not be permitted to retain the benefits of employing South Carolina residents in this capacity without submitting to jurisdiction under the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act.Â  See Hanson v. Denckla, 357 U.S. 235, 253 (1958) (stating that a courtâ€™s exercise of jurisdiction requires some act by which a defendant purposefully avails himself of the privilege of conducting activities within the forum State, thus invoking the benefits and protections of its laws).
Accordingly, we hold the Commission correctly exercised jurisdiction over Respondentâ€™s claim because Respondent was hired in South Carolina and his employment was located in South Carolina.Â  
 
III.Â  Jurisdiction when an employer has four or more employees in South Carolina.
Appellants argue that even if Respondent was authorized to file his claims in South Carolina under Â§ 42-15-10, Appellants are nevertheless exempt from the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act because Employer did not have any employees in South Carolina.Â  We disagree.
An employer is exempt from the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act if the employer has less than four employees in this State.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-360(2) (1976). Â Â 
There are numerous facts that lead this Court to conclude that Employer has at least four employees in South Carolina.Â  First, Employer is required to file with the South Carolina Employment Security Commission when it employs South Carolina drivers.Â  According to Employment Security Commission reports, Employer had more than four employees in South Carolina during each fiscal quarter of 2001 and the first quarter of 2002.Â  Employer also files income taxes with the South Carolina Department of Revenue for South Carolina employees.Â  Additionally we note that Employerâ€™s out-of-state drivers are not permitted to exercise an election to file their income tax withholding or unemployment security benefits with the State of Alabama.Â Â Â  
 
Employer claims that it has no employees in South Carolina because it has no offices, facilities, or office staff in South Carolina.Â  Employer also argues that the South Carolina income tax and unemployment filings are merely formalities required by law.Â  However, given that the crux of Employerâ€™s business requires the mobility of its employees, we will not, as Employer suggests, limit our interpretation of Â§ 42-1-360(2) to traditional jurisdictional notions of a â€œprincipal place of business.â€Â  See Lester v. S.C. Workersâ€™ Comp. Commâ€™n, 334 S.C. 557, 561, 514 S.E.2d 751, 752 (1999) (â€œWorkersâ€™ compensation statutes are to be construed in favor of coverage; any exception to workersâ€™ compensation coverage must be narrowly construed.â€).Â  
 
Under the facts and circumstances of this case, we find that Employer regularly employed more than four employees in the same business in South Carolina at the time of Respondentâ€™s accident.Â  Accordingly, Employer is not exempt from jurisdiction under the Workersâ€™ Compensation Act.
IV.  Compensability of Respondentâ€™s injuries
Appellants argue that Respondentâ€™s injuries are not compensable under the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act.Â  We disagree.Â  
 
Injuries are covered by the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act when they arise out of and in the course of employment and when they naturally and unavoidably result from the accident in question.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-1-160 (1976).Â  In our opinion, there is substantial evidence in the record to support the Commissionâ€™s finding that Respondent sustained a brain injury and a stroke (transient ischemic attack), and developed a psychological condition stemming from an accident arising out of and in the scope of his employment.
Following the accident, an emergency room CT scan indicated Respondent had a post-trauma subarachnoid hemorrhage[3] in the right parietal region of his brain.Â  At a follow-up appointment the following day, a neurosurgeon assessed Respondent and noted a closed head injury with post-traumatic subarachnoid hemorrhage and probable post-concussive syndrome.Â  During the following month, Respondent complained to the neurosurgeon of dizziness, vertigo, and light-headedness, at which point the doctor referred Respondent to neurologist Dr. R. Joseph Healy (â€œDr. Healyâ€) for a formal neurological evaluation.Â  Dr. Healy also diagnosed Respondent as having a closed head injury with post-traumatic subarachnoid hemorrhaging and post-concussive syndrome.Â  Although Respondent had no previous history of high blood pressure, the doctor also prescribed medication for treatment of hypertension.Â  As Respondent continued under the care of Dr. Healy, he continued to complain of sleeplessness, numbness in his left hand, and hearing loss.Â  Â Â 
On Respondentâ€™s third visit, Dr. Healy overheard a confrontation between Respondent and his workersâ€™ compensation nurse about whether the nurse would remain in the examination room during Respondentâ€™s exam.Â  When Dr. Healy entered the room to begin the exam, he observed that Respondent was very agitated and had extremely high blood pressure.[4]Â  During the exam, Respondentâ€™s blood pressure remained at an elevated level.Â  Respondent complained of a headache, dizziness, and left arm numbness; the doctor also noted high blood sugar.Â  Concerned that Respondentâ€™s symptoms were related to his high blood pressure, Dr. Healy listed Respondent as suffering from a transient ischemic attack[5] and admitted him to the hospital that day.Â  
 
Respondent continued under Dr. Healyâ€™s care and, with medication and modifications in his diet, Dr. Healy found that Respondentâ€™s conditions were improving.Â  However, based on the poor results from Respondentâ€™s sleep study and Respondentâ€™s decreased ability to focus and perform tasks, Dr. Healy did not yet believe that Respondent was fit to return to work as a truck driver, and requested neuropsychological testing.Â  The neuropsychological examination revealed that Respondent suffered from depression, mainly due to his head injury, and partly due to marital problems.
According to Dr. Healy, Respondentâ€™s underlying medical problems were exacerbated by Respondentâ€™s closed head injury and the confrontation with the workersâ€™ compensation nurse.Â  Dr. Healy also explained that it was his opinion that the changes in Respondentâ€™s lifestyle resulting from his inability to work ultimately led to Respondentâ€™s depression.Â  
 
Whether there is any causal connection between employment and an injury is a question of fact for the Commission.Â  The Commissionâ€™s decision must be affirmed if the factual findings are supported by substantial evidence in the record.Â  Sharpe v. Case Produce, Inc., 336 S.C. 154, 159-60, 519 S.E.2d 102, 105 (1999).Â  Substantial evidence is that evidence which, in considering the record as a whole, would allow reasonable minds to reach the conclusion the Commission reached. Id. at 160, 519 S.E.2d at 105.Â  The possibility of drawing two inconsistent conclusions from the evidence does not prevent the Commissionâ€™s finding from being supported by substantial evidence.Â  Id.Â  

Based on Respondentâ€™s medical records, the opinion of Respondentâ€™s treating neurosurgeon, and reports of Respondentâ€™s confrontation with the workersâ€™ compensation nurse, we find that there is substantial evidence in the record to support the Commissionâ€™s conclusion that Respondent sustained a physical brain injury, stroke, and developed a psychological condition in conjunction with an accident arising out of and in the scope of his employment.Â  Accordingly, we affirm the circuit courtâ€™s finding that Respondentâ€™s injuries are compensable under the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act.
Conclusion
For the foregoing reasons, we hold that the circuit court erred in failing to decide the issue of jurisdiction over Respondentâ€™s workersâ€™ compensation claim.Â  Furthermore, we affirm the Commissionâ€™s findings and hold that the Commission had jurisdiction over Respondentâ€™s workersâ€™ compensation claim.Â  Finally, we affirm the decision of the circuit court finding that Respondent suffered compensable injuries under the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act.
MOORE, WALLER, JJ., and Acting Justice G. Thomas Cooper, concur.Â  PLEICONES, J., concurring in part, dissenting in part in a separate opinion.Â   


JUSTICE PLEICONES:Â  I agree that the circuit court erred in failing to address the jurisdictional issue, but would hold there is no evidence that Respondent was hired in South Carolina.Â  The drug testing, road testing, and orientation conducted in Alabama were not â€œsimply incidentalâ€ to Respondentâ€™s hiring, but in fact the determinative acts.Â  Had Respondent failed either test, or failed to complete orientation, he would not have been hired. In fact, he was not hired, until his successful completion of these tasks.Â  Moreover, in determining whether the â€œbase of operationsâ€ is in South Carolina, the focus is the employerâ€™s base, not the employeeâ€™s.Â  By focusing on the employeeâ€™s residency, the majority ignores the legislative decision in adopting S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-15-10 (1985) to reject the â€œdomicile and employmentâ€ rule.Â  See Holman v. Bulldog Trucking Co., 311 S.C. 341, 346Â Â  428 S.E.2d 889, 892 fn. 2 (Ct. App. 1993).Â  

Â Accordingly, I would hold that South Carolina lacks jurisdiction over Respondentâ€™s workersâ€™ compensation claim.Â  
 

[1] This employee received a $500 referral bonus from Employer for recruiting Respondent.
[2] Employer argues that Respondent could not have been hired over the phone because the Department of Transportation (DOT) prohibits hiring truck drivers before the administration of a drug test.Â  This argument is misapplied.Â  Although the federal government requires a person seeking to drive a commercial vehicle to pass a drug test and a road test before driving a commercial vehicle, there is no obligation on an employer to perform these tests before hiring a truck driver employee.Â  49 C.F.R. Â§ 391.41 (2006).Â  See also 49 C.F.R. Â§ 382.301(a) (requiring that drug testing be done â€œprior to the first time a driver performs safety-sensitive functions for an employerâ€).
[3] Respondentâ€™s neurologist explained that subarachnoid hemorrhaging occurs when there is bleeding between the middle membrane covering of the brain and the brain itself.Â Â Â 
 
[4] Additionally, we note Dr. Healyâ€™s efforts to settle the matter between Respondent and the workersâ€™ compensation nurse.Â  Although the nurse claimed a need to stay in the room during the doctorâ€™s visit in order to â€œgather information,â€ Dr. Healy informed the nurse that by law, the patient had the right to see the doctor alone.Â Â  Dr. Healy noted in his office records, â€œThe Workmanâ€™s Comp is very confrontational which I think is very inappropriate.â€Â  
 
[5] Respondentâ€™s neurologist described a transient ischemic attack as a condition indicating the patient has nearly had a stroke.

title: Oxendine v. Davis
description: In this case, the Court held that the lower courts properly determined that Dwight Oxendine was employed in South Carolina for the purpose of determining Workersâ€™ Compensation coverage.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court

	
		
			
				Dwight Oxendine, Respondent,
				v.
				Christine Davis, d/b/a Johnny Davis Construction Company, Employer, and Travelers Property & Casualty Co. of America, Carrier, Appellants.
			
		
	


Appeal from Marion County
Â James E. Lockemy, Circuit Court Judge
Opinion No. 26331
Heard November 15, 2006 - Filed May 21, 2007Â Â  

AFFIRMED


	
		
			
				F. Reid Warder, Jr., and Jason A. Williams, both of Wood, Porter & Warder, of Charleston, for Appellants.
				James C. Rushton, III, of the Hyman Law Firm, of Florence, for Respondent.
			
		
	


CHIEF JUSTICE TOAL:Â  In this workersâ€™ compensation case, the single commissioner determined that the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission (â€œthe Commissionâ€) had jurisdiction over Dwight Oxendineâ€™s (â€œRespondentâ€™sâ€) workersâ€™ compensation claim because his employment was located in South Carolina.Â  This ruling was affirmed on appeal.Â  Respondentâ€™s employer, Christine Davis d/b/a Johnny Davis Construction Company, and the employerâ€™s insurance carrier (collectively â€œAppellantsâ€) argue this conclusion was incorrect.Â  We disagree and affirm the circuit courtâ€™s decision.Â Â  Â 
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Respondent was injured in an accident arising out of his employment with Johnny Davis Construction Company (â€œEmployerâ€).Â  Respondent resided in Rowland, North Carolina.Â  During the four to six years preceding his injury, Respondent framed houses for Employer during warm months and performed sheetrock work for other employers during cold months.Â  Employer was based at a home/office in Mullins, South Carolina, and nearly all of Respondentâ€™s work for Employer was performed in South Carolina.Â  Respondent was most often paid by Employer while at jobsites, but Respondent occasionally went to Employerâ€™s home office in Mullins to receive payment.Â  Respondent often received work assignments at Employerâ€™s home office and was always accountable to Employer.
In the spring of 2004, Respondent ran into Employer at a barbeque in North Carolina.Â  Employer offered him a job framing a house in Ocean Isle, North Carolina.Â  Respondent started work the following Monday and was injured six weeks later when he fell and sustained an ankle fracture which required surgery.Â  Employer took Respondent to the emergency room, and then transported him to Employerâ€™s home in Mullins.Â  
 
During the six-week period prior to his injury, Respondent worked only on the house in North Carolina.Â  Respondentâ€™s co-worker transported him to and from his residence and the jobsite, both located in North Carolina.Â  However, Respondent visited Employerâ€™s home in South Carolina for social purposes and to help Employer fix his water pump, a task for which Respondent was not paid.Â  Respondent also traveled to Employerâ€™s home to receive payment at least once during this period.Â Â  
 
Respondent filed a workersâ€™ compensation claim in North Carolina and was denied coverage.Â  Respondent then filed for medical and compensation benefits under the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act.[1]Â  Appellants denied entitlement to benefits.Â  At a hearing before the single commissioner, the primary issue was whether Respondent met the statutory requirement for filing a workerâ€™s compensation claim in South Carolina; specifically, whether Respondent was hired in South Carolina, injured in South Carolina, or whether his employment was located in South Carolina.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-15-10 (1976). 
 
Both parties agree that Respondent was hired and injured in North Carolina.Â  The parties disagree, however, on the location of Respondentâ€™s employment.Â  Respondent argued the Commission had jurisdiction because his employment was located in South Carolina. Â The single commissioner agreed.Â  Both the full commission and the circuit court affirmed, and this appeal followed.Â  We certified this case for review pursuant to Rule 204(b), SCACR, and Appellants raise the following issue for review:

	Did the circuit court err in affirming the Commissionâ€™s holding that Respondentâ€™s employment was located in South Carolina?

STANDARD OF REVIEW
Appellate review of workersâ€™ compensation decisions is governed by the Administrative Procedures Act.Â  Shealy v. Aiken County, 341 S.C. 448, 454, 535 S.E.2d 438, 442 (2000); see also Lark v. Bi-Lo, Inc., 276 S.C. 130, 276 S.E.2d 304 (1981).Â  The Full Commission is the ultimate fact finder.Â  Shealy, 341 S.C. at 455, 535 S.E.2d at 442.Â  Under S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 1-23-380(A)(5) (Act. No. 387, 2006 S.C. Acts 387, eff. July 1, 2006), a reviewing court determines whether the Full Commissionâ€™s findings of fact are supported by substantial evidence in the record and whether the panelâ€™s decision is affected by an error of law.Â  Baxter v. Martin Bros., Inc., 368 S.C. 510, 513, 630 S.E.2d 42, 43 (2006).Â  
 
When the Commissionâ€™s jurisdiction is at issue, this Courtâ€™s review is governed by a preponderance of the evidence standard.Â  Gray v. Club Group, Ltd., 339 S.C. 173, 181, 528 S.E.2d 435, 439 (Ct. App. 2000); see also Wilson v. Georgetown County, 316 S.C. 92, 94, 447 S.E.2d 841, 842 (1994) (â€œ[W]hen the Commissionâ€™s jurisdiction is at issue, as in this case, the reviewing court is not bound by the Commissionâ€™s findings of fact upon which jurisdiction is dependent.â€).Â  â€œIn determining jurisdictional questions, doubts of jurisdiction will be resolved in favor of inclusion of employees within workersâ€™ compensation coverage rather than exclusion.â€Â  Wilson, 316 S.C. at 94, 447 S.E.2d at 842 (citing White v. J.T. Strahan Co., 244 S.C. 120, 135 S.E.2d 720 (1964)).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Appellants argue the Commission did not have jurisdiction because Respondentâ€™s employment was located in North Carolina.Â Â  We disagree.
An employee covered by the provisions of the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act is authorized to file his claim under the laws of the state where he is hired, the state where he is injured, or the state where his employment is located.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-15-10 (1976).Â  In order to determine where a claimantâ€™s employment is located, South Carolina has adopted the â€œbase of operations rule.â€Â  Voss v. RAMCO, Inc., 325 S.C. 560, 482 S.E.2d 582 (Ct. App. 1997); Holman v. Bulldog Trucking Co., 311 S.C. 341, 428 S.E.2d 889 (Ct. App. 1993). Â Under the base of operations rule, â€œthe workerâ€™s employment is located at the employerâ€™s place of business to which he reports, from which he receives his work assignments, and from which he starts his road trips, regardless of where the work is performed.â€Â  Holman, 311 S.C. at 346, 428 S.E.2d at 892 (citing Holland v. W.C.A.B. (Pep Boys), 586 A.2d 988 (Pa. Commw. Ct. 1990)).
In Holman, our court of appeals held a truck driverâ€™s employment was located in Georgia.Â  The driver resided in South Carolina and worked out of a flatbed trailer terminal in Savannah, Georgia.Â  Id. at 343, 428 S.E.2d at 890.Â  The driver was both hired and injured in Georgia.Â  The driver argued that under Â§ 42-15-10, an employeeâ€™s employment could be located in more than one state when the employee travels into other states and conducts substantial business there.Â  Id. at 345, 428 S.E.2d at 892.Â  The court disagreed and held the driverâ€™s employment was located in Georgia because that is where the driver â€œreported to his employerâ€™s place of business for duty, where he picked up and returned his company truck, where he received his work assignments and from which he was dispatched, where he called in during the course of his work, and where he returned weekly when he had completed his work.â€Â  Id. at 346-47, 428 S.E.2d at 893.Â  
 
In Voss, the court of appeals held a traveling salesmanâ€™s employment was located in South Carolina.Â  The salesman, a Texas resident, was hired in Dallas by a representative for a South Carolina company.Â  Voss, 325 S.C. at 563, 482 S.E.2d at 583.Â  The company shipped equipment to the city in which the salesman was located and the salesman would negotiate sales requiring him to call the company office in South Carolina two to five times a day.Â  Id. at 564, 482 S.E.2d at 584.Â  The salesman was paid by either retaining a portion of the sales price or by receiving payment sent by the company.Â  Id. at 565, 482 S.E.2d at 584.Â  The salesman never sold equipment in South Carolina and traveled to this State only once.Â  Id.Â  He was injured in Washington.Â  
 
The Voss analysis was based on Holmanâ€™s proposition that the employeeâ€™s place of employment can only be in one state.Â  Id. at 570, 482 S.E.2d at 589.Â  The court distinguished Holman because it applied the base of operations rule in order to fit â€œneatly within the employment ritual of the employee truck driver in that case.â€Â  Id.Â  Under the Holman base of operations analysis, the Voss salesman would have no place of employment because he did not report to any place of business, nor did he receive work assignments from a particular place, or start his road trips from a particular locale.Â  In light of the legislatureâ€™s intent to broaden the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Act by amending S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 42-15-10 in 1974,[2] the court reasoned that a personâ€™s employment must be located in some state.Â  Id. at 572, 482 S.E.2d at 588.Â  The court determined the Voss salesman was principally employed in South Carolina because it was the only state in which he had any base of operation.Â  Id.Â  The court noted that although this situation did not fit squarely within the base of operations test, South Carolina was the state where the salesman was employed considering the high degree of control exerted over him by his superiors who were located in South Carolina.Â  Id.Â  
 
Like the Voss salesman, Respondentâ€™s situation does not fit squarely within the base of operations test.Â  Respondent received his work assignment in North Carolina and began his road trips from his North Carolina residence.Â  His work-related contact with Employerâ€™s South Carolina home/office was limited during the six-week employment period prior to his injury.Â  Despite this, we believe the following factors are illustrative: (1) Respondent regularly worked for Employer in South Carolina during warm months for a number of years; (2) Respondent went to Employerâ€™s home/office in South Carolina on occasions to be paid, including at least once during the last interval of his work; (3) Respondent often met co-workers at the place of employment to go to jobs; and (4) Respondent performed work at Employerâ€™s home immediately before his injury.Â  Respondent was also taken back to Employerâ€™s home/office in South Carolina immediately following his injury.Â  Although none of these factors are individually determinative, they all lend support to the conclusion that South Carolina was the location of Respondentâ€™s employment.Â  This conclusion is underscored by the amount of control exerted over Respondent by Employer who was located in South Carolina.Â  See Voss, 325 S.C. 560, 482 S.E.2d 582.
In reaching this conclusion, we look not only at Respondentâ€™s six-week employment term, but also at his broad employment history with Employer.Â  Respondentâ€™s regular and recurring employment with Employer for several years prior to his injury was nearly entirely based in South Carolina.Â  The fact that Respondent was working in North Carolina on this particular occasion does not transport the Employerâ€™s base of operations from South Carolina to North Carolina.Â  
 
Appellants contend the base of operations rule does not apply to this case because Respondent is not a transient worker like the truck driver in Holman or the salesman in Voss.Â  We disagree.Â  This case presents a classic example of nomadic employment.Â  Respondent, an itinerant construction worker, did not work at a single location.Â  Rather, he traveled to jobsites wherever he was needed.Â  
 
Appellants also argue that if the base of operations rule applies, the relevant base of operation was North Carolina because it is the employeeâ€™s base, and not the employerâ€™s base, that should be considered.Â  Appellantsâ€™ reasoning directly contradicts both Voss and Holman; cases which apply the base of operations rule to determine the location of nomadic employment based on the employerâ€™s place of business, â€œregardless of where the work is performed.â€Â  Holman, 311 S.C. at 346, 428 S.E.2d at 892.Â  In the instant case, Employer clearly operated his business out of his home in South Carolina.Â  Therefore, Employerâ€™s base of operation was in South Carolina.Â  
 
CONCLUSION
Applying the base of operations rule, we find Respondentâ€™s location of employment was South Carolina. Â Therefore, we hold that the South Carolina Workersâ€™ Compensation Commission has jurisdiction over Respondentâ€™s workersâ€™ compensation claim.Â  The decision of the circuit court is affirmed.Â 
 

MOORE, WALLER, PLEICONES, JJ., and Acting Justice G. Thomas Cooper, concur.
[1] S.C. Code Ann. Â§Â§ 42-1-10 to 42-19-50 (1976 & Supp. 2005).
[2] Prior to the 1974 amendment to Â§ 42-15-10, an employee injured outside the State could file a claim in South Carolina only if (1) his contract of employment was made in this State; (2) the employerâ€™s place of business was in this State; (3) the employeeâ€™s residence was in this State; and (4) the contract of employment was for services to be performed not exclusively outside this State.Â  The amended statute liberalizes the requirements by making the conditions for filing alternative rather than conjunctive.Â  See Holman, 311 S.C. at 345, 428 S.E.2d at 891-92.

The South Carolina Court of Appeals

  
    
      
        Raymond C. Harrison, #316664, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
        Sherry Diane Harrison, Defendant.
         
      
    
  

The Honorable Robert N. Jenkins, Sr.
Anderson County
Trial Court Case No.Â Â  2007-DR-04-0000B

ORDER

Raymond Harrison, Appellant, is currently incarcerated.Â  He sought to file for a divorce from his wife.Â  He filed a summons and complaint with the county clerk of court, as well as a motion and affidavit to proceed in forma pauperis.Â  He did not include any filing fees with his summons and complaint or the motion.Â  The motion to proceed in forma pauperis was denied.Â  Appellant then filed a motion for reconsideration.Â  He received from the Chief Deputy Clerk of Court for Anderson County a letter that read:

  We forwarded your Motion for Reconsideration to the Honorable Robert N. Jenkins, Jr., who had denied your Motion for In Forma Pauperis.Â  Judge Jenkins returned your Motion for Reconsideration to our office and states he will not amend his decision.

Appellant filed this appeal with a caption that reads Ex Parte Raymond Harrison v. The State, In re Raymond Harrison v. Sherry Diane Harrison.[1]Â  Appellant also has filed a motion to proceed in forma pauperis in this court in which he indicates he has no means of earning an income while incarcerated and has no assets with which he can pay the filing fees.
In Lakes v. State, 333 S.C. 382, 510 S.E.2d 228 (Ct. App. 1998), this court found the order denying Lakesâ€™ request to proceed in forma pauperis effectively discontinued the action because Lakesâ€™ only means of bringing the action was in forma pauperis, and therefore, the order was immediately appealable.Â  In Ex Parte: Martin v. State, 321 S.C. 533, 471 S.E.2d 134 (1995), the supreme court addressed when an inmate may proceed in forma pauperis.Â Â  The supreme court held: â€œIn the absence of a statutory provision allowing the general waiver of filing fees, we conclude motions to proceed in forma pauperis may only be granted where specifically authorized by statute or required by constitutional provisions.â€Â  Id. at 535, 471 S.E.2d at 134-35 (citations omitted).Â Â  The supreme court went on to state:Â  â€œFurther, where certain fundamental rights are involved, the Constitution requires that an indigent be allowed access to the courts.Â  Id. at 535, 471 S.E.2d at 135 (citing as an example Boddie v. Connecticut, 401 U.S. 371, 91 S.Ct. 780, 28 L.Ed.2d 113 (1971) (an indigent must be given access to courts in divorce action)).
The United States Supreme Court stated in Boddie:Â  â€œdue process requires, at a minimum, that absent a countervailing state interest of overriding significance, persons forced to settle their claims of right and duty through the judicial process must be given a meaningful opportunity to be heard.â€Â  Boddie, 401 U.S. at 377.Â  The court summarized its position by stating:Â  
 

  [G]iven the basic position of the marriage relationship in this societyâ€™s hierarchy of values and the concomitant state monopolization of the means for legally dissolving this relationship, due process does prohibit a State from denying, solely because of inability to pay, access to its courts to individuals who seek judicial dissolution of their marriages.Â Â  
	 

Id. at 374.
The facts of this case indicate Appellant is indigent and seeks access to this court to appeal the denial of his motion to proceed in forma pauperis in the family court.Â  Boddie clearly requires Appellant be allowed to proceed in forma pauperis both in this court and in the family court.
Appellantâ€™s motion to proceed in forma pauperis in this appeal is granted.Â  Additionally, we reverse the family courtâ€™s order and remand this case to the family court to allow Appellant to proceed in forma pauperis in his family court action.Â  
 
AND IT IS SO ORDERED.

  
     
    C. Tolbert Goolsby, Jr.                  ,  J.
       John W. Kittredge,                         ,  J.
    Jasper M. Cureton,                          ,  A.J.
  

Columbia, South Carolina
5/16/2007
